Context:
Program Name: Screenwriting & Narrative Design
Code: P400
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 1 year (3 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $8,741.00
International Tuition: $27,280.00
Location: St. James Campus
Program Overview: The one-year Screenwriting & Narrative Design postgraduate certificate program provides students with the necessary knowledge, writing experience, and skills to excel as a screenwriter in various media industries. The program also focuses on narrative design for gaming and interactive storytelling.
Courses: Not provided in the text.
Program Description: The Screenwriting & Narrative Design postgraduate certificate program helps students write well-structured stories within linear and nonlinear contexts. Students will learn about character development, dialogue, scene construction, setting, texture, style, tone, and language variances in storytelling for film, TV, games, and interactive media. They will also collaborate with fellow students on student-led projects and potential research projects.
Requirements: Students need a laptop capable of running Final Draft and MS Office, a Netflix subscription, and a stable/high-bandwidth Internet connection.
Related Programs: Video Design & Production (P112), Screenwriting & Narrative Design (Online) (Postgraduate) (P410), Media Foundation (P111).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Screenwriting & Narrative Design Program (Postgraduate) P400 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. Potential job titles for media writers: script writer, assistant producer, advising writer, creative writer, content writer, interactive media writer, staff writer, editor, story editor, showrunner, narrative designer, creative designer, script consultant, story consultant, freelance writer.
2. Locations where professional storytelling/writing/content development is concentrated: Toronto, Vancouver, Los Angeles, New York.
3. Required courses in the first semester: WRIT 1001 (Intensive I – Writers' Room), WRIT 1002 (Writers' Studio I), WRIT 1003 (Story and Character I), WRIT 1005 (Feature I), WRIT 1006 (Video Game), WRIT 1010 (Episodic I), WRIT 1017 (Entrepreneurship).
4. Required courses in the second semester: WRIT 1004 (Story and Character II), WRIT 1007 (Entertainment Business), WRIT 1012 (Writers' Studio II), WRIT 1015 (Feature II), WRIT 1016 (Interactive).
5. Required courses in the third semester: WRIT 2001 (Thesis Project).
6. Program Learning Outcomes: Produce linear and non-linear narrative content to industry standards using current and relevant software, Create content employing traditional and non-traditional dramatic narratives with advanced application for entertainment writing within linear and non-linear mediums, Articulate the differences between the varying mediums’ production processes and how the writer integrates into each process, Investigate the varying guilds, associations, agencies and groups and how they interact with relevance to the different industries, Differentiate the history of film, television, video games.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Screenwriting & Narrative Design Program (Postgraduate) P400 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information on various aspects of a program offered by the college related to entertainment and media studies. Here are some key factual information extracted from the text:

- The program covers interacting with different industries, history of film, television, video games, and interactive media, production and distribution landscapes, employment preparation, research methods, emotional response to audience, and evaluation of personal and recognized works.
- Tuition fees for domestic students for three semesters starting in Fall 2023 is $8,741.00, while international students for the same period is $27,280.00. However, it's important to note that these amounts are subject to change and do not include the cost of books which are to be purchased separately by the student.
- The text mentions Fall 2023 and Fall 2024 as starting dates for programs.
- The college offers a variety of skills training, including interview skills, presentation skills, resume writing, proposal development, pitch preparation, and research methods using online and library resources.
- The program covers both traditional and interactive narratives, and techniques in character development and narrative structures.

Therefore, the extracted information includes the following factual entities:

- Program topics: Interacting with industries, history of film, television, video games, production and distribution landscapes, employment preparation, research methods, emotional response to audience, and evaluation of personal and recognized works.
- Tuition fees for domestic students: $8,741.00 (three semesters starting in Fall 2023)
- Tuition fees for international students: $27,280.00 (first three semesters starting in Fall 2024)
- Starting dates for programs: Fall 2023 and Fall 2024
- Skills training offered: Interview skills, presentation skills, resume writing, proposal development, pitch preparation, and research methods using online and library resources.
- Narrative types covered: Traditional and interactive narratives.
- Techniques covered: Character development, narrative structures, plot analysis, characterization, setting, dialogue, point of view, structure, length, originality, manipulation of point of view, analyzing form and structure, comparing setting and atmosphere, and assessing personal and recognized works for traditional composition techniques.

Context:
The text provides information about applying to the School of Media & Performing Arts at George Brown College. Here are some key facts extracted from the text:

1. International students should visit the "International Fees and Related Costs" page for information on fees, and the "International Admissions" page for country-specific admission requirements. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
2. The program requires a bachelor’s degree, two- or three-year diploma, or graduate certificate (postgraduate studies), along with a resume and writing samples or demonstrated competence through related work experience (minimum 3 years in entertainment industry or performing arts). Domestic applicants submitting international transcripts require a Canadian equivalency evaluation from ICAS or WES.
3. Students can apply for financial assistance, which is approved for OSAP funding if the applicant meets eligibility criteria. The information contained on the website is subject to change without notice.
4. Contact information: Email - media@georgebrown.ca, Phone - 416-415-5000, ext. 2015. There is also an international contact us page for recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin. The School of Media & Performing Arts is located at the St. James Campus at 230 Richmond Street East.
5. For more information on course exemptions, students can visit the Transfer Guide. Students should verify George Brown College fee requirements.
6. Disclaimer: Information contained in this website is subject to change without notice and should not be viewed as a representation or warranty.

Context: Performing Arts campus located at 230 Richmond Street East, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Programs offered include Video Design & Production (P112), Screenwriting & Narrative Design (Online, Postgraduate, P410), and Media Foundation (P111). Notable alumnus Mitchell LeBlanc won the 2017 Reddit Screenwriting Contest and placed top 10% in the Academy Nicholl Fellowship. Graduates' work can be viewed online. Campus tours are offered regularly. Contact George Brown College to book a campus tour or sign up for tailored resources and application information.
